item.title: Debate Moderators Didn't Ask Trump How He Planned to Create Jobs
item.description:
So I was very proud of the policies we put forth. You know, I kept waiting for the moment – I, you know, I’ve watched a million presidential debates in my life and I was waiting for the moment when one of the people asking the questions would have said, well, so exactly how are you going to create more jobs, right? … I thought at some moment that would happen.

— Hillary Clinton, 2017 Women for Women International annual luncheon

Claims:

Debate Moderators Didn't Ask Trump How He Planned to Create Jobs
The Truth:
They did in 2 of the 3 debates.

Fact Checks:

FactCheck.org
But it did happen. Twice. Both Holt and Wallace devoted an extensive part of their debates to job creation and the economy. Trump told both moderators that he would create jobs by renegotiating trade deals, cutting regulations, reducing business taxes, and repatriating corporate cash held overseas.

item.title: Donald Trump Opposed Rescuing the US Auto Industry
item.description:
Back in the Great Recession, when millions of jobs across America hung in the balance, Donald Trump said rescuing the auto industry didn’t really matter very much. He said, and I quote again, “Let it go.”

— Hillary Clinton, campaign event at Wayne State University

Claims:

Donald Trump Opposed Rescuing the US Auto Industry
The Truth:
He consistently supported doing so.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact

Trump is documented as saying just the opposite during the recession. He regularly said the auto industry needed saving amid a low point for manufacturers in December 2008. He said the government should stand behind the auto industry “100 percent.”

Clinton also takes the “let it go” quote out of context and time. Trump made that comment in 2015, not 2008. And he was making the point that a number of actions could have saved the auto industry, one of which was “let it go” into bankruptcy.

item.title: Hillarly Clinton Was the Only Candidate in 2016 Who Pledged Not to Raise Taxes on the Middle Class
item.description:
I am the only candidate who ran in either the Democratic or the Republican primary who said from the very beginning I will not raise taxes on the middle class.

— Hillary Clinton, rally in Cleveland, OH

Claims:

Hillarly Clinton Was the Only Candidate in 2016 Who Pledged Not to Raise Taxes on the Middle Class
The Truth:
15 of 17 Republican candidates pledged not to raise taxes on anyone, including the middle class.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
Fifteen of the 17 Republican presidential candidates signed pledges not to raise taxes on anyone, which includes the middle class. Thirteen of those candidates signed the vow last year; the other two inked such a pledge earlier in their careers. Trump wasn’t one of them, but Clinton specifically mentioned the primary field. And that makes the claim both inaccurate and ridiculous.

item.title: Comey Said Clinton Was Truthful With the American Public About Her E-Mails Server
item.description:
Director Comey said that my answers were truthful and what I said were consistent with what I told the American people…

— Hillary Clinton, interview with Chris Wallace

Claims:

Comey Said Clinton Was Truthful With the American Public About Her E-Mails Server
The Truth:
He said the FBI “had no basis to conclude she lied to the FBI”, and that he was unqualified to answer about the American public.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact

Talking specifically about Clinton’s closed-door FBI interview, Comey said there is “no basis to conclude she lied to the FBI” about her email practices. But Comey has specifically declined to comment on whether Clinton’s public remarks have been accurate.

Further, while not explicitly rebuking Clinton’s public comments, Comey highlighted a major problem with them.

Clinton repeatedly said she did not have any classified information whatsoever in her email, marked or unmarked. After the FBI investigation, including the interview with Clinton, Comey said she unequivocally did.

item.title: Hillary Clinton Landed in Under Sniper in 1996 in Tuzla, Bosnia
item.description:
I remember landing under sniper fire.

— Hillary Clinton, speech on Iraq ware at George Washington University

Claims:

Hillary Clinton Landed in Under Sniper in 1996 in Tuzla, Bosnia
The Truth:
It didn’t happen.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
There’s no doubt flying into Bosnia was dangerous back in 1996, but the threat of sniper fire is not the same as actual sniper fire, and hustling off the tarmac is not the same as running with your head down. Yes, Clinton later acknowledged that she was mistaken, but it’s hard to understand how she could err on something so significant as whether she did or didn’t dodge sniper bullets. Quite simply, this kind of hyperbole deserves our harshest assessment. We rule Pants on Fire.

item.title: Obama Basically Threatened to Bomb Pakistan
item.description:
Last summer he basically threatened to bomb Pakistan, which I don’t think was a particularly wise position to take.

— Hillary Clinton, Democratic Presidential candidates debate

Claims:

Obama Basically Threatened to Bomb Pakistan
The Truth:
He didn’t.

Fact Checks:

PolitiFact
We might give Clinton points for qualifying her remarks with “basically.” But even with that qualifier, she is twisting Obama’s comments to imply he wants to attack a U.S. ally. It’s not enough to call that False. We called it Pants-on-Fire wrong when McCain said it and we’re doing the same for Clinton.
